commentBody: More of a Monday level difficulty.  It was fun, with a cute theme. I don't mind cuteness.
New Wednesday PR here by a mile. That was *very* breezy for midweek! Charmingly free of Yoko ONO, TNOTES, TBARS, OLLAs, and other chestnuts, tho.
That would have been an outstanding time for a Monday.
Not to be too nitpicky, but a more accurate clue for 5D would be "Smallest five-digit integer".
Nice Wednesday puzzle. Got the puns pretty quickly. Some nice toothiness for a Wednesday but relatively fast solve.

Was the constructor from Virginia? One entry refers to Camp Peary, another to Quantico ‚Äî both Virginia bases for their respective agencies. Had they worked in another entry for Langley, the game would‚Äôve been over.

Regarding Sam's question about 28A:
Yes, you are overthinking it.
Cheese dogs are good, expand your mind!
Congratulations on your debut, Ilana!  Really enjoyed this puzzle. Clever and fun. CHEESEDOG AND DELIVERYMAN made me laugh out loud. Thanks!

Anyone seeing a lot of problems with how comments are appearing (or not appearing)? Anyone also write to the NYTgames and get replies that explain away all these bugs as if they are normal and "streamlining" and to be expected? Anyone write to them again, explaining in more detail what is going wrong with the comments, and get (72 hours later) a reply that echoes the first, but a little more condescendingly? This is bringing out my worst self. 

Got a light, dude?
FIRE MAN?

For anyone wondering if my Constructor Notes were omitted, here they are (yes, I‚Äôm vain enough to care, sadly):

I am so stoked to be sharing a byline with Ilana on her NYT debut! We met in the "Cruciverb" Facebook group, which is where I met my mentor (now NYT rockstar) Christina several years ago in the same fashion: as a new constructor looking for feedback on a few early construction attempts. I have to say, it was a bit awkward for this 50-something man to dole out constructive criticism to a younger woman whose puzzle included the theme entry MANSPLAINING‚Äîit's like I was asking for trouble! Nonetheless, I persevered because I wanted to pay Christina's kindness forward. Who knew it would ultimately result in today's puzzle?

For aspiring constructors, the editing staff's wise advice Ilana referenced: they wished all of our theme entries had more transformative clues. While STAY AT HOME DAD [Going shopping without you, Pop!] and STUDY BUDDY [Hit the books, slacker!] were cute, they were too literal; STAY AT HOME and STUDY change parts of speech, but the general meaning is unchanged. This made them less clever than, say, TWISTED SISTER or BLOCKBUSTER. Wordplay is key.

To Ilana: thanks for the "mentor" props. It's an honor, even if I don't consider myself anyone's mentor. This was a true collaboration. How awesome is it that the very first idea we worked on together is running in today's New York Times?? Or, perhaps more appropriately: Can you believe it's RUNNING, MATE?!
A fun theme that was well executed.
Fun puzzle. I had upgrades for 9D initially which slowed me down a bit.
Feeling kind of confused here.  40A.  How does "axes" fit for "origin crossers"?  what am I missing?

EMMA Thompson intersecting with ANG Lee? Must be a sign to rewatch Sense and Sensibility. 

The other night on a Jeopardy repeat, the final Jeopardy answer was something like What two people have won Nobel prizes in two different fields? One was Marie for chemistry and physics and the other was Linus Pauling for chemistry and peace.

The themers here were fun. I found the Acrosses somewhat difficult, but the Downs were kind to me.

Nice job, Ilana and Scott.
Happy to report a personal Wednesday best on this one! Haven‚Äôt seen one of those in a while and I‚Äôm quite pleased with it. ü§ò

I found this puzzle easier than yesterday's - I finished it in Tuesday time. The clueing was very straightforward for Wednesday, wasn't it? The theme seemed Monday-ish. It was not a bad puzzle but maybe it should have run on another day. I don't get one thing - Origin crossers: AXES? Are these AXES as a plural of axis or axe? I'm feeling completely lost here. Is my poor knowledge of math to blame, and my even worse ability to describe in English what little I do know of math? The puzzle doesn't ring many Polish bells, but the one it does ring is a big one. Marie Curie, or more accurately Maria Sk≈Çodowska-Curie, was Polish, and her achievements have been celebrated here for decades. She is considered one of the most significant people in our history - hers is one of the first historic names kids learn in school. Strangely, for a long time only a very minor street was named after her in Warsaw. So when a major new bridge was built recently, it was given her name, too. She is also the patron of many Polish schools and research institutes, including several in Warsaw. Her biography is fascinating and well worth a read: https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marie_Curie

It really didn't read as an easy puzzle, but it sure filled in quickly. Beat a lot of my Monday times, and although not quite my fastest Wednesday, it's one of the quickest.

A variety of not-so-common answers and some clever themers made this an enjoyable exercise.

Thanks, Ilana and Scott!

I too felt it was pretty easy for a Wednesday, though the top half filled in faster for me than the bottom. Had PsS for a long time and couldn't get sORTEN_ to solve to anything and had forgotten what a tin lizzie was. As soon as I switched to PPS it all came together and I got the gold star.

I was going to ask what a CHEESE DOG was but given Sam‚Äôs comment, I‚Äôll pass. 

Thanks 

Nice Wednesday puzzle.

Congratulations, Ms. Levene, on a fun NYT debut! You and Mr. Hogan delivered an amusing puzzle. I particularly liked BLOCK, BUSTER. 

Thanks!

Best Wednesday time by a mile. I agree with those who think this was maybe a bit too easy for mid-week, but that didn‚Äôt make it any less enjoyable. First class, mates!

And now I‚Äôm hungry for a cheese dog‚Ä¶
Really enjoyed this one.  Thank you for an excellent puzzle.
The Wednesday puzzle like Monday and Tuesday is too easy!
I filled in 26A with PORTENT because of the fantastic comic strip Cul de Sac by the late Richard Thompson. And look at what today's comic is! https://www.gocomics.com/culdesac/2025/05/21

Very enjoyable.  I'm borderline with doing Wednesday puzzles, but this one went fairly easily.   Bottom right I had "exterior" which messed things up until I finally figured out "external."
      "Sostenuto" is the Italian version of "sustain" which is a standard musical notation for holding a note a bit longer, or spreading out a musical phrase.

Is anyone having any issues with their subscription log in? I did the crossword 7 hours ago on my PC, as I have done for years, but when I went back to it just now, it‚Äôs asking me to subscribe. I tried logging in but I‚Äôm stuck in a loop. 
I‚Äôm sending this from my phone which still has me logged in, under my Games subscription.

That was a pun fuzzle - all in the clues. Not all that quick for me of course; none of the theme answers dawning on me just from the clues, but they all came together with some crosses. Nice 'aha' moments for all of them. Was really surprised to see that four of the theme answers were debuts, as they were all quite familiar terms. Puzzle find today was inspired by 'Tin Lizzie.' A Sunday from July 18, 2013 by Andrew Reynolds with the title: "Fast Work." Hard to describe this one. Some of the answers... HENRYFORD TINLIZZIE MODELT ASSEMBLYLINE But... there was a whole lot more to it than that. You'd have to go take a look to get it. Here's the link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=7/28/2013&g=78&d=D I'm done. ...

I enjoyed the puzzle but thought the clue for ‚Äúrehear‚Äù could have been better. I thought for sure I had something wrong there and was going to have to change an across answer but no-that was all correct.
Fun and quick 1 cup of coffee puzzle for a Wednesday. Nice. Now for the slog, finding my typo. Argh...
Thought for sure this was a PB, but apparently I did a Wednesday in 5 minutes at one point. Missed it by a few seconds
Money, makers.

Really enjoyed this puzzle! I'm sure it was too easy for a Wednesday for some, but I like a breezy mid-week crossword. Plus, I really enjoyed the themed clues, outside of CHEESE DOG, which I don't really understand.

This was my fastest Wednesday ever, and I see I am not alone. On a different subject, the NYT keeps vacillating over the length of my streak. It seems undecided about something that occurred 17 days ago, switching every few days from a streak in the 200s to a short streak and then back. I see nothing but gold stars when I look. This doesn‚Äôt bother me the way it might have a few years ago, but the oscillation is curious. Does this happen to others?

Of course, it‚Äôs very satisfying to successfully fill in the box.  But this puzzle had much more to pad the experience.

Beauty in answers, for one, adding radiance.  Gorgeous words: SHARD, LITHE, SLIVER, PORTENT, STOLID.

Lack of ugliness.  Look at the finished grid, how clean it is ‚Äì as I scan it, my whole system calms down.

A theme that delivers:
‚Ä¢	Sweet wordplay.  How the first word of the theme answers changes meaning from the normal phrase to its meaning in this puzzle.
‚Ä¢	Brain-happifying riddle cracking, trying to guess the theme answers with as few crosses as possible.
‚Ä¢	Freshness.  Four of the five theme answers (excepting BLOCKBUSTER) are NYT debut answers, and worthy ones, bringing the patina of newness to the box.

Smile-triggering serendipities.  The cross of EYE and SEE and a quartet of three-letter palindromes in EYE, HUH, WOW, and CDC.

Thus, a solve plumped with pleasure, satisfying indeed.  Ilana, congratulations on your debut, and Scott, kudos on your first NYT 15x15 after four Sundays. This was a gem, and thank you both!

Nicely straightforward. I found this easier than yesterday's. 

Fortunately the car names filled themselves in.

The theme was funny, although I didn't understand the 'dog' either. And someone has just answered that, thank you.

I very confidently wrote "say chEese" and "say youR tees" thinking I'd cracked the theme... before the crosses made absolutely no sense for me.

Also down with the SICKNESS made me smile.
Three easy peasies in a row no doubt confirms that tomorrow will be a bear.

I keep hearing these phrases in the voices of either The Dude"l from Big Lebowski or Spicoli from Fast Times at Ridgemont High and I can't stop giggling. https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=bMtdrKIdDgE ‚ù§Ô∏èü§£‚ù§Ô∏èü§£‚ù§Ô∏è

This one was quite easy but took 28A on my part. A few were a tad 10D, but clever as heck. Great job, Scott, the subtle theme was very witty.

Stolid or stoic; I just loved the confusion that created. Thanks for that distractor, bro. Gah! Or is it argh!

Cruella‚Ä¶ brilliant performance for the pair of Emmas! That quickly became one of our favorite movies of this modern age.

Funny observation; Any humorous reference made by we ‚Äúboomers‚Äù at work would inevitably elicit an off-handed ‚Äúdad joke‚Äù comment by the millennials. We did observe the cultural phenom of showing each other memes from their phones, and giggling. How creative (?) That's gold, Jerry‚Ä¶ gold, can I use that?

40A I don't get it, nor does 42A ring any kind of bell. And I need to definitely add lithe to my dwindling vocabulary.

53A ‚ÄúAlone‚Äù might have been more apropos and fit nicely. "In tune" seems unattainable, at least in my case.

Try again? Rehear? Wow. Mind‚Ä¶ blown. Brilliant, Scott!

42D location, affectionately known as ‚ÄúThe Farm.‚Äù If I tell you more, you'll get ‚Äúvisitors‚Äù at your door.

Ectoplasm. Who else pictured Egon Spengler and Dr. Venkman dripping in the stuff?

Lizzie should have been capitalized. Now I'll read in the comments why it shouldn't have been. 

"Dog" for "dude" seems OK, but CHEESEDOG? [DOESNT SEE YET, he says, while reading the easternmost column in the grid.] I mean, who would ever put cheese on a frankfurter?

Liked the theme, and the puzzle seemed solid, albeit a bit gentle for a Wednesday offering. LITHE, PORTENT, STOLID, and SPLURGES were interesting *words*.

NOTBAD, if not quite WOW!

Lovely, refreshing Wednesday puzzle. Guaranteed rebus-free (was pest control involved?). CHEESEDOG made me smile, and, with the other clever theme entries, was perfectly punsensible. FERMI and CURIE are old friends, and the car models were not difficult. 

Now, as to why the NYT is making me sign in again every time I want to do a different puzzle... or could it be the devious computing machine? 

Very nice start to the day. Hats off to the constructors!
I was delighted to see Enrico and Marie in today‚Äôs puzzle! This was a breeze, but a pleasant one.

This was so much fun! It went by very quickly (tied my best Wednesday time to the second!) but that's in part because I was so entertained that I wanted to get to the next theme clue. Very fun; great job, constructors!

"Awww, you shouldn't have. An artificial nuclear reactor, Fermi?"


 Truly delightful theme! Well done!


"Are acrosses columns?"

"Rows, bud."
What a difference a week makes. Compared to last Wednesday, today was gentle, man!
Breezy...went down like honey!

For some reason today the NYT website doesn‚Äôt think I have a full access description. I can sign on through the iPhone app and see that I have a paid up full access subscription so it‚Äôs on NYT end. You know what‚Äôs more annoying than not being able to access the website? Having a customer service bot tell you that it understands your frustration. Finally got through to a human and was told techs are working on it and I should try again in a few hours. 

I thoroughly enjoyed this silly theme. But I‚Äôm a sucker for lame humor that knows it‚Äôs lame.
14 seconds off a PB. If I'd known, I'd've skipped those sips of coffee!
More like a Tuesday puzzle!  Fun though.
I do like a CHEESE DOG or two. If I want to SPLURGE, I'll top them with jalapenos and onion SLIVERs. With some potato CHIPs on the side.

Ilana Levene and Scott Hogan
NOTBAD, a STAR cuz you SHAR'D.

I tripped right thru this puzz.

22D‚ÄîAfterthought's afterthought: Abbr.
PPS could've been PPB, then 30A could be changed
to BLOG.  
That was the only area I had trouble with. 
Maybe it was PPS to up the difficulty to Wednesday.

PS‚ÄîI drove the Chevy VOLT to the levee but the levee wasn't dry.

PPS‚ÄîThere are no EXTERNAL chargers at the levee.

PPPS‚ÄîI met this chick in an ALTIMA. Her name is
IN√âS CUERVO but she goes by IN√âS CROW en Ingl√©s. 
We're all out of rye so we're drinking rum n coke.

PPPPS‚ÄîIN√âS and I getting along great! I told her she's
so mysterious, so EMMA PEEL, she laughs and calls me
Mister Yosa. Earlier she was calling me Dickey when we 
were chatting about the levee. Luv her accent.

PPPPPS‚Äî"Mi maletero est√° lleno." means "my trunk is full
in Spanish...who knew?! I helped IN√âS wrassle some of the
biggest, heaviest trashbags outta her trunk. She sez her NINO
will take care of them.
Anyway, we're off to some party...IN√âS sez its revolutionary!
I'm in!

I was just sure I had already commented...but it has been one of those mornings.  DHubby wanted to get through breakfast and move on to grocery shopping; I found the lower temps ..well, tempting... so I got out the window-washing Windex hose attachment thingie, and it was off to the races.  Kinda.  Doing the ceiling of the porch is a challenge, but wasps and dirt daubers and spider make it necessary.  (I won't let the crews hired by the Village do it because they've already pressure-washed the paint off the ceiling, doors, etc.  I just say I have hired a professional to do the job...and none of my plants get crushed, as a bonus.)

Oh, the puzzle.  Cute pairs, even if it should have been DELIVERY, GUY!  Whipped through it and moved on in a good mood.  
Then I read all the CHEESE DOG mentions and feel slightly ill, especially the one mentioning chili.  I am still not over the 'chili cheese spaghetti' at Skyline on the corner of Clifton and Ludlow...circa 1974.

Add my voice to those who really enjoyed this puzzle. Cute theme, breezy, some new fill, etc. 
It wasn‚Äôt close to a PB, but beat my average. Ilana Levene and Scott Hogan have indeed made some friends here.

Given that I solved it less than an hour and there was a theme, I dug it especially for a midweek puzzle! Sadly while doing it, certain answers like CIA, FBILAB, and CDC naturally got me thinking about my True Crime fascination and how those agencies are going to be affected big time and therefore, so many people who have lost loved ones are never going to have that chance of closure so to speak. Many Cold Cases aren‚Äôt going to be solved due to the lack of support/funds from the government. Of course I‚Äôm still having SLIVERS of hope though! Anyways, hopefully my fellow NYTers are having a Wonderful Wednesday and Namaste!!
Loved this one - a perfect Wednesday!

CHEESE DOG: Pro or con? The "cheese" that you get on most CHEESE DOGS has the same relationship to real cheese as the "butter" you get on buttered popcorn has to the "real deal". Definitely con. On the other hand, the new Korean CHEESE DOGS are spreading throughout the land. This is similar to a corn dog: a hot dog on a stick, deep-fried with a core of molten cheese and an outer layer of something interesting. https://www.emmymade.com/korean-style-corn-dogs/ Color me curious.

Fun puzzle, fun theme, though I had no idea what a CHEESE DOG was til I read the comments. Um, yuk?
Today is a significant birthday for me. Not quite as LITHE as I used to be, but NOT BAD either.
Still not a pensioner as successive powers that be keep raising the pension age, so I‚Äôm not sure what that makes me, other than a punk elder.
Naturally Mother Nature chose to break the several week heat wave with a tsunami of rain fall today. Yes, the land needs it, but you couldn‚Äôt wait one more day Ma‚Äôam? I had a trip to a beautiful garden planned washed out. Thanks. I had to put up with a lunch out with DH instead ;)

Such a delightful puzzle! I admit, I purposefully slowed down my time, just to appreciate the theme answers. (Thematic answers? Whatever...) 

I usually go into Wednesday with bated breath, knowing it could always be more Thursday-ish than Tuesday-ish. And sometimes it's just plain fun. That was today. Yippee!

I appreciated seeing the clue for Camp Peary. Let's hear it for Williamsburg, VA!
 
Colonial reenactors, college students, amusement park fans, and spies. There's something for everyone! üòÄ
Wednesday PB!

This puzzle theme was a bit TWISTED, SISTER.

You owe me. PAYPAL.
I'm wondering if it was Ilana's intention that 5D-eleven is an anagram of her surname.

Hi Sam! So, *sostenuto*, literally, means "sustained," and I suppose if you sustain something, like a note, you make it longer. But as a musician, I would never consider them synonymous. I had LiNGER as well, which doesn't match by part of speech, but captures better the quality of a melody or phrase played "sostenuto."

It‚Äôs fascinating to me, as I move beyond my Monday & Tuesday solving comfort zone, how different my performance can be from one Wednesday to the next. Last week I only filled 25% of the grids before giving up. (In fairness, sometimes my time to persevere is limited.) Today was much more successful. I managed all but the northeast corner. REHEAR did not come to me, I‚Äôm not weirdly conversant with Nissan‚Äôs models (although it sounded familiar in retrospect), ERG on its own was new to me, and the wording of 21A wasn‚Äôt transparent enough ‚Äî the word ‚Äúinstrument‚Äù made me erroneously think of an inert object. I didn‚Äôt love 54A, primarily because there are some subtly different definitions of the word, but, hey, I‚Äôve got to think outside the box. But I really enjoyed the theme clues and answers‚Äî clever, funny, and satisfying to solve.

Strands #444
‚ÄúThree's a crowd‚Äù
üí°üîµüü°üîµ
üîµüîµüîµüîµ

NO SPOILERS UNTIL AFTER VIEW ALL REPLIES, PLEASE
To my mind, a cheese dog isn‚Äôt that different from a ham and cheese sandwich. ü•™ Pork product + cheese + condiments = lunch, no?

For all the American pop culture/random knowledge I pick up doing this crossword, cars just don't stick and never will. 

I don't even know car models for the country I live in.
Not exclusively related to today's puzzle, but today I reached a 2,000 day streak.
that was a fun theme

Great to see MƒÅori make an appearance! While it would definitely be too niche to be included in the NYT crossword, we'd typically refer to the language as te reo MƒÅori, or just te reo, whereas MƒÅori refers to the people. In English, most people would just call the language MƒÅori.
Breezy, barely a stumble. If only I could type well on an iPhone. A personal best with minutes to spare, all while waiting at the car dealership‚Ä¶ bittersweet.

Sweet little puzzle, (WILDHONEY, made me smile, as in the bees making it) just right for a Wednesday, but the toughies are coming. I have, however, made progress on the Friday and Saturday puzzles lately, having actually completed them with no help. But the Sunday, it tries my patience, the grid, so big, and the words, so small on my phone! Anyway, hope you all are having, or had, as the day is waning. a good one.

Oooh, so late to the party tonight, but so appreciative of this puzzle! It fairly sparkled, at least where it didn‚Äôt induce pun-groans. Glad that 32D was STAR instead of Oreo. Did not know that about 50D - an amazing person all around! 
Thank you Ilana and Scott; you‚Äôve got a winner here!
@Mitchell Obviously, I meant "Three-syllable number". Don't know what happened.
@Mitchell isn‚Äôt that what the clue says?

@Mitchell That WAS the hint, so maybe you mean "smallest three-syllable integer"?

As a mathematician, I could one-up you and insist on replacing "integer" with "natural number"... but who's counting anyway.

@Darren. [smallest three digit positive rational]. ONE TRILLIONTH?
[smallest three digit integer]. MINUS TEN?
@Patrick J. Make that last MINUS TWELVE
@Patrick J. Whoops again. Make that [smallest three syllable‚Ä¶]. Did this on my phone on a bus.

@Mitchell

Something like "one point one"? ü§î

@Patrick J. And a candidate for the smallest used positive real number: TWELFTH ROOT TWO. (Approx 1.-5946). Used? Yes, it is the factor used in the construction of the well-tempered scale, that is the ratio between the frequencies of two notes separated by a semi-tone.

@David Connell,

Looks like @Patrick J. just got a hyphen there instead of a zero. Easy enough to do on a keyboard.
@Sanders McNew My only knowledge of Langley comes from American Dad!
@Grumpy Somebody had to say it.
@Sam Corbin I concur üòÇ
@Crab My mind has expanded beyond hot dogs and melted cheese (I'm vegan), but I won't knock the fan base!

@Crab.  I‚Äôm sticking with mustard and sauerkraut!  

Carl Sagan and many others have used this apt quote, though no doubt in a less important context than the best way to eat a hot dog 
 
‚ÄúIt pays to keep an open mind, but not so open your brains fall out.‚Äù

Kidding, of course.  Our sons eat them with ketchup.  But we love them anyway.

@john ezra

I've written three times.  I thought maybe I had the ear of someone who might be able to do anything, but I've not heard anything in a couple of days.  Nothing.

I've sent extensive scenarios, with screen shots and visual aids, but nothing.  I feel like I've done the QA work that maybe isn't done at all at the NYT. Nothing.

I've written up that QA work in the style of how bugs used to  be reported to me.  Nothing.

Deb?  Sam?  Can you do anything to help us?  Nothing seems to be working.  Nothing.
@john ezra Thought it was only me. Good to know I'm not alone.

@Sam Corbin

Hi Sam, thanks for your comment. But the issues are more technical and mechanical and glitchy then about moderation of our behavior. I‚Äôm sure you have seen Steve, Barry and others, including Francis here, try to get clarity on these bugs and issues without success. It‚Äôs not a civility issue, Although my original post on this was just removed when I thought I was being extremely civil about the whole thing. That said, the problems that we are having here are technical.

Sam,

This has nothing to do with *moderation* of comments. 

It's all about changes to the comments *system* that produce unintended and/or undesirable results.

@john ezra

and even now, only 3 replies to your comment show, with nothing to indicate that there are more. Sam's comment doesn't even show!

When comments are invisible, one can't follow or contribute to a  conversation here.

Broken conversations make a broken community.

I'm assuming that the "streamlining" of the comments system is aimed at those controversial or political articles that get thousands of comments. It's probably an algorithm somewhat like Facebook's "Most relevant" filter (which is also fraught with problems.)
But we don't get thousands of comments here in Wordplay, it only becomes unmanageable on the occasional  tricky Thursday or Sunday.

The community here is why I keep coming back to do these puzzles. Breaking the community may kill the golden goose of Games for the NYT.

@john ezra and everyone 

Yes, these are confirmable and repeatable bugs in the comments *system* that have been occurring for about a month now. (I have screengrabs going back to at least early May.) Like @Francis, I took the time to document issues in the manner I would while doing QA/UAT as part of a product team -- to no avail.

As @Barry Ancona has mentioned previously, these issues occur across the NYT Digital and are not merely within the Games section. As such, it's astonishing that apparently this situation is such a low priority!

Like @Eric Hougland, I have almost completely stopped commenting because it's so frustrating. That there has been zero progress, zero communication, and indeed outright denial by Customer Support is incredibly discouraging.

@Linda Jo

Fascinating: When I refreshed the page to check if my comment posted, @john ezra's initial post indicated "5 replies". As keeps regularly occurring, only two displayed -- @Francis and @Sam Corbin -- and then (erroneously) the View All Replies button, which should only display after 3 replies. Clicked on that, the indicator changed to "8 replies" (inaccurately, as there were more than eight) and suddenly @redweather's post appeared between those other two. 

(Mind you, that's an entirely different scenario from when I first encountered the post and began my reply...)

And yet you got a completely different scenario! For the same thread! Wild.

@john ezra Dear Crossworders/Cruciverbalist Commenters: 

I have been seeing you all talk about the problem and not experienced it myself but I have an older phone. If not obsolete, it is out of date and I wonder whether the comments section is just struggling to keep up with all latest models
 of iPhone, Droid or whatever brand we have‚Äî
and to keep all of the various stakeholders happy?
@Linda Jo I was just humbly asking.
@Linda Jo Perhaps age, model or operating system of your laptop then might be relevant?

@john ezra and all

At the beginning of this month I had an exchange with one of the customer support reps.  Here is the final reply: 

"Hi John,
 
The comment section may be showing fewer replies because only direct replies to the original comment are being displayed, while nested replies (replies to replies) might not be included in the initial view. This approach could be intended to streamline the viewing experience, reducing clutter in threads with many nested responses. However, I understand this makes the VAR function appear inconsistent, especially since it used to show after 3 replies, and now it‚Äôs not triggering reliably.
 
Your workaround of clicking the timestamp to display all replies, and the fact that emailed links show all replies, aligns with this explanation, the timestamp likely forces a full thread reload, including nested replies, while the email link bypasses the streamlined view. I‚Äôve tested the thread you shared, and I can confirm the VAR button isn‚Äôt consistently appearing, which suggests a potential change in how we display replies.
 
I'll note this ticket as feedback for our team to review and consider as we continue to look for future improvements for our solvers, thank you.
Lovedeep D.
Customer Support Specialist
The New York Times"

I know others here have also received similar comments and it appears that the faulty functioning of the View All Replies button is/was part of a deliberate attempt at "streamlining" the readers experience.

Continued . . .

Sam, since you may be following this thread perhaps you could advise as to what our next step might be.  I've been mulling around creating an open letter or petition that a number of us could sign on to in order to try to convince NYT to put some resources into solving this problem.
I sent this thread to Deb Amlen with a note asking her to see what she could do to get Games to talk to IT about the matter. I got an OOO, so I forwarded the message to Everdeen Mason.

@John Carson

John I even quoted you when I wrote to them because you put it so well. Then I got these unhelpful responses from Towanda, Alex and one other person that pretended nothing was wrong etc. it was infuriating.

John Ezra

I was fortunate to get a rep who seemed to engage the the issue and even tested the sample thread that I sent them.  We agreed that the issue is the code behind how and when the View All Replies (VAR) button is displayed.

The workaround of clicking on the time/date stamp, long ago suggested by Barry, works in the same way that using the emailed link works which isolates the thread but then one must go "Back to All Comments".  

I've noticed that if the Recommend button is clicked the VAR button will be displayed if there are hidden replies.  So I'm using that workaround now if I suspect there are replies not displayed.  So it pays to like everybody here, and probably in general. :)

Barry,  

Good idea!   Hope you/we get a response.

@Linda Jo

Your post echoes my thoughts exactly. 

When I started solving the NYT puzzle every day beginning five years ago, I was happy to find a community with whom I share some interests. I‚Äôm bad at meeting people in real life and I‚Äôm now living in a new place. This comments section gives me some of the community that I had before I retired. And I have learned a lot from the smart, educated people who hang out here. 

It makes me sad to see this community fall apart because of technical issues that the NYT apparently doesn‚Äôt want to address. 

It‚Äôs not surprising that you brought up Facebook. Some of the things that I have seen there lately are almost enough to make me ditch that forum.

@John Carson

Interesting. (I have found Lovedeep D. to be knowledgeable, respectful & seemingly understanding that I have a tech background.)

One surprise in that exchange is the repeated reference to "nested responses". The NYT comments do not have nested responses! There are no indented "trees" and all comments (used to) display chronologically regardless of reply-to reference. 

All along I've suspected the Comments product team updated the commenting platform on the backend but applied the same UI as always. Who knows? But certainly some kind of conflict between code for nesting responses and the existing UI could be underlying it all... ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

FWIW, the click-timestamp "workaround" is crazy-making, and I only resort to it exceedingly rarely. The Back to All Comments link doesn't anchor to where one was in the comments, making it useless when one is well into, say, 300 comments... And I ALWAYS deselect the "Email me" checkbox. (Shared account.)


@Convoid-04

You aren't wrong that there is a ton of complexity across platforms, etc. But these major issues are (a) a dramatic change from how Comments operated even a month ago, (b) across all sorts of devices, and (c) across all of the NYT. 

Are you certain you don't experience them? Do you, for example, sometimes see the View All Replies button when there are only 2 replies to an initial post?

@Convoid-04

I wanted to get back to you on your comment about all the multiple platforms and versions within each platform.   You are correct that it must be difficult, if not impossible, for the NYT developers to test every single instance.  But I agree with G from BK's reply to you that the VAR issue occurs across all the various platforms/versions. 

I have noticed a flaw that you might be interested in.  On an older iPhone (iPhone 7, IOS 15.8.4) when the View All Replies (VAR) button is selected the entire thread disappears.  

However, on an iPhone 13, IOS 18.4.1, this does not occur.  

I have no idea if this behavior has cropped up since the changes made in late April or early May or was there before but I suspect that the bug is part of the current issues.

"One surprise in that exchange is the repeated reference to "nested responses". The NYT comments do not have nested responses! There are no indented "trees" and all comments (used to) display chronologically regardless of reply-to reference."

G,
I think they are (mis)using "nested" responses to mean replies to replies, as opposed to replies to the original post on the thread. I clicked Reply to the OP to post this, so everyone will see it. If I had clicked Reply on your reply, my post would not be seen without a timestamp click. This is "streamlining" we don't need on this forum, and I have difficulty understanding where it would be beneficial.

@Barry Ancona

Fully concur.  Well said.

This is not for you so much as for anyone who might be able to fix this.

They don't seem to be able to focus on the fact that without replies to replies, we cant have a real conversational thread in this forum.  

Sarah posts something.  John replies.  Sarah replies to John, but John cannot  see the reply because it's a reply to a reply.  You can click the time stamp, and they will magically appear, but when you go "Back to All Comments" it takes you to the TOP of the comments, and the user has to scroll through possibly hundreds of comments to get back to where they were when they clicked the time stamp.

That is shoddy, amateurish coding and user experience.

In the paper writ large, it isn't an issue because the time gap between submission and the post appearing is way too long for that, and the open comment period is way too short.  No real conversations can develop.  Here they can, and it's been a wonderful experience up to now.

If they've decided that "streamlining" (why?  it's a continuous digital display, not something we're trying to fit into a finite newspaper column) is important, then AT LEAST make it so that the "Back to all Comments" returns you to the comment on which you clicked the time stamp.

I'm blue in the face.

@Andrzej

There has been lots of responses about the "AXES", but I haven't seen any mention of the "origin".

In a (Cartesian) graph, the "origin" is where the X-axis and Y-axis intersect, with the co-ordinates (0,0).

By the way, did  you notice that one of the constructors is British?  I was wondering if that would be helpful to the non-American solvers.

@Andrzej

Actually, it just occurs to me to ask you if you have words in Polish that are spelled the same but have more than one pronunciations?

We have a lot of those.  Axes and axes is an example I've never thought of.  Likewise "effect" is pronounced two different ways depending on if it's a noun or a verb.

In fact, our most basic word "the" can be emphasized by saying "thee", as in he wasn't a hypocrite, he was the(e) hypocrite."  The "the" would be pronounced "thee".

@Andrzej - As I learned it in Poland thirty years ago, the word ‚Äúmuzyka‚Äù when pronounced with the classical Greek accentuation MUzyka means the art of music, but pronounced as a standard Polish word muZYka means a band playing for a wedding or a dance hall.

There are words with Latin plurals paralleling English plurals that people like me are careful to distinguish. Appendix meaning the bodily organ has the plural appendixes; appendix meaning additional matter in a document has the plural appendices. Ditto for indexes/indices, codex/codices, and others.

@Skeptical1

Keep in mind that the early-week puzzles are supposed to be solvable by inexperienced solvers. Read through the comments and you‚Äôll see reports of some pretty long solving times.

There are ways to make these easy puzzles more challenging. Try solving using only the Down clues. Or, when you reach a certain point (a half-filled or two-thirds filled grid), try to get as many answers as possible without looking at any more clues. 

The NYT apparently believes that we all want to have the longest streak of gold stars possible. I think that pushes people to do puzzles they would otherwise skip.

@Eric Hougland

the ad-blocking may be a peripheral issue . 
Months ago, January maybe, the system was glitching and when I had to log in, they popped up a new "terms of service" which included some fine print that seemed to say that ad blockers were forbidden. Most people don't read that far down in the terms and conditions.

I dutifully turned off my MalWare ad tracker and just ignore the ads. I don't know how other ad blockers work, but this one apparently interferes with all pop-ups including the ones that serve legitimate website functions, like log-ins and shopping carts. Like spyware and malware, adware is always in a race against the ad blockers.

@Bill
The FURIES as _instruments_ of vengeance? Another odd choice of words. In their primordial form, as the Erinyes, they were certainly vengeful, but they acted willfully, of their own accord; they didn't act as instruments, as it were--of any greater deity, like Zeus, say.

Then there was that fiasco with Orestes, in which they served as prosecuting attorneys--hung jury, DA Apollo makes a fuss, Judge Athena (who works for the same law firm--no conflict of interests there!) steps in--it's like a bad episode of Law and Order. The Erinyes demand the case be REHEARd, but no! A&A, Attorneys-at law, recruit them into some "convict rehabilitation program," and rename the Eumenides.

Eons later, they are hired by the NYT Puzzles and Games Dept., where they revert to their original personae, under the names of the Emunides.

Linus of Thrace was the music teacher of Heracles. Herc wasn't the best of students, didn't always sing in tune. During one fateful lesson, and exasperated Linus cried out "No, No, Ercole mio! Pi√π sostenuto, prego!" In anger, Hercules bonked Linus over the head with his lyre, and killed him.

Now that's what I call a Mythological instrument of vengeance!

@Bill

In the "Eumenides" the Furies *are* Clytemnestra's "instruments of vengeance," although they fail at their task (happily for Orestes).

@Bill
